newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh PM offers talks with opposition.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh PM offers talks with opposition.

text.p: Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, in a bid to defuse simmering political tension, has offered to hold talks with her main political foe and predecessor, Begum Khaleda Zia, Hasina's aides said on Tuesday.
"I am ready to sit with the opposition leader (Khaleda) to discuss any issue of national importance," they quoted Hasina as saying late on Monday.

Hasina, who took office in June last year after her Awami League defeated Khaleda's Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) in general elections, said she was ready for a live debate on television with the opposition leader on all issues.

"We have...invited the opposition leader to sit for open dialogue to explain to the people what we are doing and what the (opposition) are doing," her aides quoted Hasina as telling editors of local newspapers and news agencies on Monday night.
"We want to make everything clear to the people as we believe in the democratic system," she said.
The BNP said the government must first free detained political opponents and stop harrassing others before discussions could begin.
"A congenial atmosphere has to be created before any dialogue can take place," BNP Secretary-General Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan told a news conference in Dhaka.
Bhuiyan said Khaleda had not received any formal invitation for dialogue.

"We will only respond to any such dialogue if they (government) stop filing false cases against opposition leaders, stops arresting opposition activists and release those who have been detained," he said.
Hasina has repeatedly denied charges that her government has jailed opposition activists and has accused the BNP of sabotaging her development efforts.
The BNP enforced a general strike on March 23 in its first major offensive to destabilise Hasina's nine-month-old government.

Bhuiyan said the party would hold demonstrations nationwide on April 6 and April 12 to protest what he said was the ruling party's "oppressive treatment" of political opponents and to press other demands.
